# Introductions

## Description Logics

*Remember this?*

- Description Logic (DL) formalizes concepts, instances, and relationships.
- DL has four key definitions:
  - **concepts** are categories, e.g. *people*;
  - **individuals** are instances, e.g. *you*;
  - **properties** relate individuals, e.g. *has-age*;
  - **axioms** are logical statements, e.g. *all people have an age*.

## Web Ontology Language

*Annoyingly abbreviated as OWL.*

- OWL aims to add formal, semantic information to the *World Wide Web*.
- The syntax for OWL ontologies are available in everyone's favorite format -- XML -- but other formats are available too.
- The example below is copied from [`w3.org`](https://www.w3.org/TR/owl-xmlsyntax/).

```xml
<owlx:Class owlx:name="AllContinents" owlx:complete="true">
  <owlx:OneOf>
    <owlx:Individual owlx:name="#Eurasia" />
    <owlx:Individual owlx:name="#Africa" />
    <owlx:Individual owlx:name="#NorthAmerica" />
    <owlx:Individual owlx:name="#SouthAmerica" />
    <owlx:Individual owlx:name="#Australia" />
    <owlx:Individual owlx:name="#Antarctica" />
  </owlx:OneOf>
</owlx:Class>
```

## Unique Identifiers

*If we have DL on the web, how do we distinguish between names?*

- Internationalized Resource Identifier (IRI) tags are used to uniquely identify concepts, properties, and individuals within a particular ontology.
- All concepts, individuals, and properties have URL addresses.

- <https://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#Thing>

# Explorations

## Rust Crate

*See [`horned-owl`](https://crates.io/crates/horned-owl) on `crates.io`!*

- Concepts, individuals, and properties in OWL use URL syntax!
- If only there was a wrapper with less syntax...

```rust
// Reference: https://docs.rs/horned-owl/1.2.0/horned_owl/model/index.html#example
let b = Build::new_rc();
let top = TransitiveObjectProperty(
    ObjectPropertyExpression::ObjectProperty(
        b.object_property("http://www.example.com/op")));
```

## Python Package: `py-horned-owl`

*Thanks to PyO3 bindings, you can use [`py-horned-owl`](https://pypi.org/project/py-horned-owl/)!*

- The following example was generated with *Claude Opus 4.5 Thinking*.

```{python}
#| code-line-numbers: "|5|7-9|11-12|14-18|"
import pyhornedowl
from pyhornedowl.model import *

onto = pyhornedowl.PyIndexedOntology()
onto.add_prefix_mapping("", "https://example.org/university#")

# Classes (declare=True adds DeclareClass axiom)
for c in [":Person", ":Student", ":Faculty", ":Course", ":Department"]: onto.declare_class(c)
person, student, faculty = onto.clazz(":Person"), onto.clazz(":Student"), onto.clazz(":Faculty")
course, department = onto.clazz(":Course"), onto.clazz(":Department")

# Properties
for p in [":teaches", ":enrolledIn"]: onto.declare_object_property(p)
teaches, enrolled_in = onto.object_property(":teaches"), onto.object_property(":enrolledIn")

# Hierarchy & constraints
onto.add_axiom(SubClassOf(student, person))
onto.add_axiom(SubClassOf(faculty, person))
onto.add_axiom(DisjointClasses([student, faculty]))
onto.add_axiom(EquivalentClasses([onto.clazz(":Instructor"), faculty & teaches.some(course)]))
```

## Individuals & Assertions

*Populating the ontology with data.*

- The following example was generated with *Claude Opus 4.5 Thinking*.

```{python}
#| code-line-numbers: "|1-4|6-10|12-14|"
# Individuals
dr_smith = onto.named_individual(":DrSmith")
alice = onto.named_individual(":Alice")
cs101 = onto.named_individual(":CS101")

# Class assertions
onto.add_axiom(ClassAssertion(faculty, dr_smith))
onto.add_axiom(ClassAssertion(student, alice))
onto.add_axiom(ClassAssertion(course, cs101))

# Property assertions
onto.add_axiom(ObjectPropertyAssertion(teaches, dr_smith, cs101))
onto.add_axiom(ObjectPropertyAssertion(enrolled_in, alice, cs101))
```

## Querying the Ontology

*Extracting information from our knowledge base.*

- The following example was generated with *Claude Opus 4.5 Thinking*.

```{python}
#| code-line-numbers: "|1-3|5-6|"
# List all declared classes and properties
print(f"Classes: {[str(c).split('#')[-1] for c in onto.get_classes()]}")
print(f"Properties: {[str(p).split('#')[-1] for p in onto.get_object_properties()]}")

# Is Alice a Student?
print(f"Is Alice a Student? {ClassAssertion(student, alice) in [a.component for a in onto.get_axioms()]}")
```

# Case Study: Python

## Python: Classes & Properties

*Modeling the Python ecosystem.*

- The following example was generated with *Claude Opus 4.5 Thinking*.

```{python}
#| code-line-numbers: "|5|7-10|12-14|"
import pyhornedowl
from pyhornedowl.model import *

py = pyhornedowl.PyIndexedOntology()
py.add_prefix_mapping("", "https://example.org/python#")

# Classes
for c in [":Language", ":Library", ":Framework", ":DataType", ":Builtin"]: py.declare_class(c)
language, library, framework = py.clazz(":Language"), py.clazz(":Library"), py.clazz(":Framework")
datatype, builtin = py.clazz(":DataType"), py.clazz(":Builtin")

# Properties
for p in [":hasLibrary", ":dependsOn", ":hasBuiltin"]: py.declare_object_property(p)
has_library, depends_on, has_builtin = py.object_property(":hasLibrary"), py.object_property(":dependsOn"), py.object_property(":hasBuiltin")

# Hierarchy: Framework is a subclass of Library
py.add_axiom(SubClassOf(framework, library))
py.add_axiom(SubClassOf(builtin, datatype))
```

## Python: Individuals

*Populating with real Python entities.*

- The following example was generated with *Claude Opus 4.5 Thinking*.

```{python}
#| code-line-numbers: "|1-5|7-12|14-17|"
# Individuals
python = py.named_individual(":Python")
numpy, pandas, django, flask = [py.named_individual(f":{n}") for n in ["NumPy", "Pandas", "Django", "Flask"]]
int_type, str_type, list_type = [py.named_individual(f":{n}") for n in ["int", "str", "list"]]

# Class assertions
py.add_axiom(ClassAssertion(language, python))
py.add_axiom(ClassAssertion(library, numpy))
py.add_axiom(ClassAssertion(library, pandas))
py.add_axiom(ClassAssertion(framework, django))
py.add_axiom(ClassAssertion(framework, flask))
for t in [int_type, str_type, list_type]: py.add_axiom(ClassAssertion(builtin, t))

# Property assertions
py.add_axiom(ObjectPropertyAssertion(has_library, python, numpy))
py.add_axiom(ObjectPropertyAssertion(has_library, python, pandas))
py.add_axiom(ObjectPropertyAssertion(depends_on, pandas, numpy))
```

## Python: Queries

*Querying the Python knowledge base.*

- The following example was generated with *Claude Opus 4.5 Thinking*.

```{python}
#| code-line-numbers: "|1-3|5-6|8-9|"
# What's in our ontology?
print(f"Classes: {[str(c).split('#')[-1] for c in py.get_classes()]}")
print(f"Properties: {[str(p).split('#')[-1] for p in py.get_object_properties()]}")

# Is Django a Framework?
print(f"Is Django a Framework? {ClassAssertion(framework, django) in [a.component for a in py.get_axioms()]}")

# Is Django a Library? (by inference: Framework âŠ‘ Library)
# Direct assertion check (no inference):
print(f"Is Django a Library (direct)? {ClassAssertion(library, django) in [a.component for a in py.get_axioms()]}")

# Inference-aware check using ancestor classes:
django_classes = {a.component.ce for a in py.get_axioms() if isinstance(a.component, ClassAssertion) and a.component.i == django}
is_library_inferred = library in django_classes or any(str(library) in py.get_ancestors(str(cls)) for cls in django_classes)
print(f"Is Django a Library (with inference)? {is_library_inferred}")
```
